title: Smart motorways under review in wake of Telegraph investigation into driver safety
text:
Smart motorways are under review, the Transport Secretary has said, in wake of The Telegraph's investigation into driver safety.

Grant Shapps told MPs "we know people are dying" on smart motorways but added greater detail is required on how safe they are compared to full motorways.

He insisted he wants to ensure all motorways in the country are "as safe as they possibly can be".

His confirmation of the review comes after Highways England chief executive Jim O'Sullivan told the Transport Select Committee that smart motorways with a hard shoulder only used at busy times are "too complicated for people to use".

He said it will not build any more "dynamic" smart motorways because too many motorists do not understand them.

Earlier this month, The Telegraph reported how a coroner warned smart motorways can "confuse" motorists who may not know whether a hard shoulder is open or closed to traffic placing lives at risk.

Emma Brown, West Midlands area coroner, wrote to both Highways England and the Chief Coroner alerting them about her concerns following an inquest into the death of an eight-year-old boy on the M6.

Dev Naran was killed instantly when the Toyota Yaris car he was in pulled up on the hard shoulder near Castle Bromwich in May last year.
